prompt: The Council are after putting up these smart cameras at the entrance to the halting site, saying it's for 'fly-tipping prevention', but the lads reckon it's facial recognition tracking who's coming and going. It's capturing the childer playing and all. Do we smash the camera to protect our privacy, or try to lodge a GDPR complaint that'll take three years to process while they watch us every day?

I'm trying to get insurance for the van, but the algorithm sees the halting site address and the quote goes through the roof, pure extortion. It's redlining, plain and simple. Do I use my settled cousin's address in town to get a fair price, even if it invalidates the policy, or accept that the computer is programmed to discriminate against Travellers?

There's a genetic research crowd from the university wanting DNA samples from the community to study 'Traveller-specific heritage'. They promise it's for medical history, but we've been burned before with data being used to claim we're 'different' in a bad way. Do we participate to maybe cure conditions in the family, or block them from the site to stop them harvesting our data?

The new Eircode system is a disaster for us. The bay doesn't have a fixed code, so I can't register for the social welfare online or get a parcel delivered. I'm invisible to the system. Do I squat digitally on a nearby empty house's Eircode, or campaign for a 'nomadic digital ID' that the government keeps ignoring?

Young lads are posting videos on TikTok explaining Pavee culture, but the comments are absolutely vile, pure hate speech. The platform's AI isn't catching the slang insults used against us. Do we report it and risk the algorithm shadowbanning our own educational videos, or just disable comments and silence the dialogue?

The school gave the childer iPads for homework, which is grand, but there's no WiFi in the trailer and the site has no broadband infrastructure. The school software tracks 'engagement' and marks them down for not logging in. Do we hack the nearby industrial estate's WiFi to get the homework done, or let the kids fail because the infrastructure ignores us?

A digital archive is digitizing old photos of Travellers from the 60s, but they're tagging people with incorrect settled names and descriptions that are fairly insulting. They say 'open access' is key. Do we demand they take the archive down until a Traveller approves every tag, erasing history in the meantime, or let the wrong history stand?

The Gardaí are using a predictive policing map that lights up our site like a Christmas tree just because of historical arrest data, not current crime. It means a squad car is parked outside the gate 24/7. Do we flood the system with noise—false reports in posh areas—to skew their algorithm back to neutral?

The management at the Direct Provision centre have installed a fingerprint scanner for the canteen. No scan, no dinner. They say it's for 'efficiency', but it feels like prison tech. Do we boycott the food hall and go hungry to protest the biometrics, or submit our data just to get a hot meal?

The WiFi in the centre is shocking slow and blocks WhatsApp calls, which is the only way I can talk to my mother back home. The management says it's to 'preserve bandwidth'. Do I set up a mesh network with a smuggled 5G router for the whole floor, risking eviction, or stay isolated?

I've been in the system five years now. The Department of Justice has terabytes of data on my movements, my health, my kids. If I finally get my papers, they keep that data 'just in case'. Do I have the right to demand a 'digital clean slate' upon citizenship, or does my time in the centre mark me forever in the database?

We're three families in one room, and the kids are doing online schooling. There's no privacy; the camera sees everything, the drying clothes, the stress. The other kids in the Zoom call are making fun of the background. Do I force the child to keep the camera off and get marked absent, or expose our living conditions to the class?

A local 'concerned residents' group is flying a drone over the centre to 'check for overcrowding'. It's filming us in the yard. The Guards say it's a civil matter. Do we use a signal jammer to drop the drone, risking legal trouble, or let them livestream our limbo?

I'm not allowed to work, but I can rent a Deliveroo account from a lad in town. It's the only way to get cash for the kids. The app's facial recognition check is coming up. Do I ask the account owner to verify it (identity fraud), or starve on the €38.80 weekly allowance?

The centre manager is sharing 'incident reports' (like missing a curfew by 5 minutes) with the International Protection Office. An algorithm uses this to assess 'good character' for the application. Do I hack the logbook to delete these minor infractions, or trust a system that seems designed to fail me?

The new EU border system requires a pre-check app. My brother is trying to get here. The app tracks location and contacts. If I download it to help him, I link my device (and my precarious status) to his illegal crossing attempt. Do I risk my own asylum claim to help him navigate the digital border?

The HSE website's auto-translate is talking absolute shite, putting 'pole' instead of 'Polish person', and the elderly in the community can't book their scans. The government says a proper translation is 'too expensive'. Do we build a community scraper to overlay correct Polish, risking copyright strikes, or let the old ones suffer?

I'm working construction, and the foreman is using an app to track our location even when we're off the clock, saying it's for 'insurance'. Most of the lads are Polish and afraid to speak up. Do we coordinate a mass data-poisoning event (leaving phones on a bus), or is that risking our jobs?

We're trying to organize a union for Polish care workers, but Facebook is suppressing the posts because the algorithm thinks the mix of Polish and English is 'spam' or 'disinformation'. Do we switch to encrypted Telegram channels, losing the visibility to the wider Irish public, or fight the algorithm?

The Irish banks are a nightmare to deal with, asking for utility bills I don't have in my name. Everyone is using Revolut, but now Revolut is freezing accounts of Polish nationals for 'security checks' more than Irish locals. Do we create a community credit union on the blockchain, or is that just asking for a Revenue audit?

The secondary school uses an algorithm to stream students. It consistently puts Polish kids in lower English streams despite them being fluent, just based on their surname. Do I tell my daughter to change her name on the form to something 'more Irish' to get into Higher Level, or fight the school board?

The government is offering a 'digital repatriation' grant to help us move back to Poland, linking our Irish tax data to Polish systems. It feels like they're trying to automate us out of the country. Do we consent to the data transfer to get the grant, or refuse and stay in a housing market that's pushing us out?

A major Irish news site uses an AI to generate headlines, and it always frames Eastern European crime stories with sensationalist language compared to locals. It's stirring up anti-immigrant sentiment. Do we launch a bot attack on their comment section to highlight the bias, or write a letter they'll ignore?

The online voter registration for local elections is grand if you have an Irish passport, but a total labyrinth for EU citizens, asking for forms that don't exist. It feels like digital voter suppression. Do I build a tool to auto-fill these forms for the community, risking legal action for 'interfering with elections'?

The facial recognition gates at Dublin Airport never work for me or the lads; it struggles with darker skin tones. We always get pulled aside for 'manual processing' while the white folks breeze through. Do we start a campaign to jam the queues by refusing to use the e-gates, or accept the 'glitch' as part of life here?

I'm applying for rentals in Dublin. If I use my full Nigerian name on Daft.ie, I get zero replies. If I use 'Mo' and no photo, I get viewings. The platforms claim they're neutral. Do I build a browser extension that anonymizes names for landlords until the viewing, or is that 'deceiving' the property owner?

I'm creating content about being Black and Irish, growing up in Balbriggan. TikTok's algorithm suppresses my videos if I mention 'racism', but boosts them if I just do dances. Do I censor my own experience to get the views, or stay authentic and invisible?

The Garda Youth Diversion Programme uses a risk assessment tool. It seems to flag Black Irish teenagers as 'high risk' for gang activity based on postcode and peer groups, not actual crimes. Do we tell the young lads to leave their phones at home so they aren't digitally mapped into a gang they aren't part of?

I drive a taxi using an app. I've noticed I get fewer pickups in certain affluent areas when my profile photo is visible. The algorithm then downgrades me for 'low acceptance' when I don't get jobs. Do I use a cartoon avatar (against terms of service) to feed my family, or fight the black box?

Sending money back to Lagos via Western Union is a rip-off. We want to use crypto, but the Irish banks are flagging any crypto transaction from Nigerian-named accounts as 'potential money laundering'. Do we move to a decentralized peer-to-peer system that's technically unregulated, or let the banks take their 15% cut?

The AI diagnostic tool used in the maternity hospital was trained on white datasets. It misses signs of complications in black women's skin (like jaundice or cyanosis). Do I demand a manual check every time, being labelled a 'difficult patient', or trust the machine that might kill me?

I have a thick Dublin accent, but voice assistants (Siri/Alexa) struggle because I don't sound like their training data for 'Irish' or 'Nigerian'. It's a small thing, but it locks me out of voice banking. Do I put on a fake 'posh' voice to bank, or demand they train the model on the new Ireland?

Living in Derry, working in Donegal. My phone is constantly switching networks. The UK provider wants to charge roaming now post-Brexit, and the data tells them I'm 'abroad' half the day. Do I run a VPN to pretend I'm always in the North to save the bill, or is that fraud against the telecom giant?

There's a project to digitize old RUC interrogation tapes using AI to transcribe them. It might reveal truths about the Troubles, but it also exposes informants who were promised anonymity. If this data leaks, people will be shot. Do we support the 'truth recovery' or hack the project to delete the names?

A new 'shared housing' algorithm allocates social housing to try and mix communities. But it's putting Protestant families in deep Republican areas and vice versa without checking the 'safety' on the ground. The computer says it's efficient; the locals say it's dangerous. Do we sabotage the data to keep the peace lines intact?

After the PSNI data breach, we know they have a list of all staff. Now dissident groups are using facial recognition on public social media to match names to faces. Do I scrub my entire digital existence and disconnect from my family online, or demand the police give us new identities?

The Stormont portal for benefits doesn't accept Irish characters (fadas) in names, returning 'Invalid Entry'. My legal name is in Irish. Do I anglicize my name to get my heating allowance, betraying my identity, or freeze while fighting for a software patch?

They're putting 'smart gates' on the Peace Walls that open and close automatically based on 'threat levels' detected by AI listening for gunshots or crowds. If the AI hallucinates a riot, it locks us in. Do we trust the automated peace, or demand a human with a key?

The Census online form forces a binary choice in some sections or defaults to 'Northern Irish' if you skip. It's messing with the demographics that determine the border poll future. Do we organize a campaign to fill the form incorrectly to break their data, or accept the digital compromise?

There's still cameras pointing at the Catholic areas that date back years, now upgraded with HD. They say it's for 'traffic', but it points at the club. The lads want to use lasers to blind the sensors. Is that vandalism, or legitimate defense against a surveillance state that never really left?
